column4: you should do it like this:    for i in *.zip; do gunzip "$i"; done
if you want to do it for all zip files in subdirectories, too, you can:    find . -type f -name '*.zip' | while read x; do gunzip "$x"; done
it's worth remembering those 2 as templates.  they come in very handy for operating on lots of files
install package 'cdrdao" by running "sudo apt-get install cdrdao" in a terminal
i don't know why but i still get "suffix ignored" with "find . -type f -name '*.zip' | while read x; do gunzip "$x"; done"
try this:   find . -type f -name '*.zip'  | while read x; do echo gunzip $x; gunzip "$x"; done
then you'll see the gunzip commands printed before they're run, and have more idea of what's going wrong.
try it, and paste the line that appears just before the error message
I'm being an idiot...  gunzip isn't for unzipped .zip files - it's for uncompressing .gz files.  that's your problem!
find -type f -name '*.zip' | while read x; do unzip "$x"; done
if you just want to play them, give the .bin file to mplayer directly.
I don't use thunderbird, so I'm not sure, but try ~/.mozilla/thunderbird/
that's a guess based on the fact that firefox stores its stuff in ~/.mozilla/firefox...
unmount with "umount /mount/point" and eject with eject?
